intro: Hemithrinax rivularis var. savannarum, commonly known as the savanna palm, is a tropical plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Arecaceae family, characterized by its slender, unbranched trunk and pinnately arranged leaves. The plant typically grows in wetland or swampy areas, adapting to saturated soil conditions. Its leaves are long and narrow, often reaching several meters in length, and it produces small, clustered flowers followed by edible fruits. This species plays an important ecological role in its habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife.
